reviewText: After almost 2 hours I managed to finish espisode one. I realy enjoyed the humor and art style. Sometimes walking within the game can be a bit tedious. It is also quite a short game currently. Although, the soundtrack almost makes it worth the purchase alone... Well worth it if you get it now for just over 4 US dollars. But the original asking price seems to be a bit steep with the current ammount of features.\n\nTL;DR: worth it if you can buy it on sale.
voteText: 28 of 30 people (93%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
This game was reviewed using a code sent by the developer.
A bumbling English gentleman goes on an adventure to discovery the mystery murderer.

I have to say, I did have a lot of fun, and I found myself laughing out loud at times at the dialogue. I have a lot of time for games that actually include voice acting in point and click adventures, as they really make it a better experience, and Bertram Fiddle's dialog is extra special with the witty English humour, puns and plenty of pop-culture references.

Story is well presented. The game starts out with your characters wife (I assume it's his wife) ordering you to get a proper job, but first she sends you on an errand, to get her dog groomed! This is when the plot starts! This is the first part of what I assume to be three or four more games.

Controls, these are pretty much a formality. Point and click with your mouse to interact with objects. There is standard inventory system too. I didn’t like how some of the item combinations were really random, and it took me looking up one or two of the answers in order for me to progress

This episode took me roughly an hour and a half to complete, which is standard it seems for an episodic type game. I am really looking forward to episode 2 now!
voteText: 47 of 63 people (75%) found this review helpful 5 people found this review funny

reviewText:
The Adventures of Bertram Fiddle is a game that should be one of the most popular games on Steam. I cannot believe (at the time of writing this review) there have only been 3 reviews, because I know that not everyone writes reviews for games, but there are still only about 30 people who have bought it. Its MADNESS! Anyways, on with this review:

Its a hilarious point & click adventure set in Victorian London 1884, featuring adventurer Bertram Fiddle and his sidekick Gavin as they try to solve the case of Geoff the Murderer. There were a few puzzles, but they weren't too easy or too hard. I really loved the humour and the way the story all came together. I can't wait for the next episode.

OVERALL VERDICT: I really enjoyed this game, and can't wait for the next episode!
8/10

reviewText:
Enjoyable point & click adventure.

It plays nice: the voiceovers are great, soundwork is nice, writing is good, animation is good, gameplay is nice if a bit short (~90 minutes or so), you have to enjoy puns (beware the alley-gate-oar).
It runs in 1280x720 (or in 848x480, which is presumably good for tablets?) and it runs well on my old XP box, so that's nice.

I'd say it's priced about right for what it delivers.
voteText: 17 of 19 people (89%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
The graphics are fun and quirky but the game was far too easy to be enjoyable; a young child of 6 years old on the other hand would probably love it. However, due to the double entendres throughout the game, I question whether it would be suitable for them either.

As each chapter progresses, the inventory becomes empty each time, making the puzzles extremely straight forward and linear. If the items were more obscure, It would encourage the user to think a bit more for themselves. It would definitely help one to engage with the story. I like a challenge!

Due to the short length of the game, I didn't feel like I got to 'know' the characters enough to really like or connect with them. Bertram's voice was like nails on a chalk board but I could put up with his whines if the murder investigation had more twists and turns, allowing his 'hoity toity', humourous personality to shine through.

If the sequel encapsulated more of the above, I would definitely give the franchise another chance because the potential is there for a good game.
voteText: 22 of 32 people (69%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
A very amusing, but short, point and click puzzle game. The art style is what interested me in the first place and it didn't disappoint me. The art style and the characters are all very charming to watch and listen to. The huge amount of terrible puns are very amusing to me, but I can understand if that's something you'd find to be annoying and grating. The story is mildly interesting, but it's the way it's portrayed that was very good, or at the least laughably bad, depending on your taste. Not many different mechanics are used, mostly just pointing and clicking and at one point you're forced to do a chase sequence which I really didn't see coming.
Whilst playing I noticed only one bug, heads that didn't move with the body, and at one point my game froze, but that was very easy to fix. I didn't notice anything else.
This game doesn't have very high system requirements. Settings you can choose on the other hand are very limited; music on/off, subtitles on/off, a few screen resolutions options and some not very clear graphics quality options. There are only two problems I have with this game. Why is the frame rate locked at 60 fps? Also, this game is very short two and a halve hours at the most. (If you really suck, or your house catches fire or something)
Honestly, I'm going to recommend this game, but I'd wait for a sale. I think there just not enough game to warrant the price at which it is sold. If there's a sale or it's sold in a bundle with the other episodes, than I'd fully recommend The Adventures of Bertram Fiddle.

reviewText:
Great little Adventure game. Nice cartoony style and a sense of humor to match. A very promising first episode.

However, hardcore Adventure game fans may find the puzzles to be a bit too easy. Also, Bertram Fiddle's tablet roots are obvious. It has very big hot spot areas that are clearly built for touch. Also, other than what's needed there's very little to click on.

Still a great little game. Perfect game for both kids and adults. It's like playing a really nice and funny cartoon.

reviewText: The voice acting is great, and the unique, cartoon art style is phenomenal. The soundtrack is good and befitting for the Victorian setting and creepy story but gets a bit repetitive with a mix of three or so tracks? The animation is pretty smooth and makes the slowness of walking between screens excusable. The puzzles are easy and predictable but not too bad. In addition, there are amusing references to other works of literature; cough, H.P. Lovecraft and Edgar Allen Poe, cough.\n\nI would recommend this game to any fan of point and clicks or anyone intrigued by the art style. However, considering it is divided in episodes and a playthrough is about 1-2 hours with hardly any replay value, I recommend you buy it on sale because the full price is a bit much for a short and simple game.

reviewText:
Very charming point-and-click adventure game.  I enjoyed the art style and general design of the world, and the voice acting, especially, was quite well done.  A lot of games try to be funny, but really aren't; Dreadly Business manages to succeed in actually being amusing, and some of the humor is Monty Python-esque.  There are a number of innuendos that an older crowd will catch, but nothing explicit, so I do not believe it would be too inappropriate for a younger set, either.

Puzzles are intuitive and simple without being insulting; if you are looking for a challenge, however, you will not find it here: few, if any, of the puzzles will force you to think too much.  The pacing is good, and while there will be a bit of backtracking in any game of this genre, Dreadly Business keeps it to a minimum.

Many other reviewers have mentioned the length, and while it is somewhat short (Steam clocks my playthrough at about 3 hours, and there was a bit of idle time in that - many others put it at around 2 hours), I believe the quality makes it easily worth the current $5.99 price tag.  It is an enjoyable romp that can be played in a sitting.

reviewText: The series is a comical farce of living in England back in the day and the humor never lets up. Which means we should see more of the same in the next chapter should it get funded. They’re not exactly a dynamic duo, but unlike a certain French detective they’re at least not bumbling through the case. Which means hilarity with some intelligence sprinkled throughout the investigation.\n\nhttp://cliqist.com/2015/11/01/expect-adventures-bertram-fiddle-episode-2/

Very charming point and click adventure game. Loved the art style and the voice acting. Rather short first episode at around 90 minutes, but very enjoyable game. Look forward to the second episode.

I really liked the graphics style and voice acting. The story is interesting as well. The puzzles were logical and made sense, which is a good thing, but were too predictable and easy, which is not a good thing. The game feels very linear, puzzles are solved in a given order one after another. The action sequences where you have to avoid obstacles don't fit in, but they were not as annoying as they could have been.\n\nDon't get me wrong, I enjoyed this episode and am looking forward to play the sequel. But I hope for some more point-and-click adventure" instead of "interactive fiction"."

This is an awesome little game. It's witty and imaginative and a great mixture of goof, pop culture, and cartoonish creepiness. The only downside to it is that it's so short--two hours of fun and I'm done with the first installment and wishing I could stay immersed in the wacky Victorian world the game resides in.

To confirm what everyone else has said, yes, it's short. That being said, it's open about being episode one, so that's to be expected. It is also somewhat easy, however I'm thinking episode two would be a bit tougher. Overall though I must say the game is really enjoyable for what it is. I found myself enjoying the puns, and the art design, and the fact that I found a glitch that allows there to be two Bertrams on the screen (not a gamebreaker). I recommend it at the price I got it ($4.79 Canadian), and think that it's base price is fine, and will me more understandable as future episodes come out. I'm aware they're all sold separately, but they're all inexpensive, so that's just fine.\n\nAs a game, it's about a 15/20, but as a first act of a larger game, it's at least an 18/20

Cons: Puzzles are not much of a challenge

If you're a fan of old school point and click adventures with a sense of humor, you'll likely enjoy the game as much as I did.

If you're ok with paying 8 euros for a bit more than an hour of gameplay, go ahead. It's VERY short and the puzzles are pretty straightforward but the design of the world and script are awesome, pretty good voice acting too! There are lots of puns and some inside jokes as well (including a Dalek reference for them Doctor who fans). It was a fun hour and I'll be waiting for the next installments.

tl;dr: the first episode is an easy, short (1.8h) and very enjoyable adventure with a charming hero and great humor.\n\nI liked this game for the hilarious characters (Bertram himself  is funny enough) ,well placed references to games/movies/music and the overall charming/drolly artwork and humor. The price is good enough I guess, but I'd rather just spend $20+ on the full game with all episodes.  I'm definitely not going to buy any other episodes until they release a full game, if they ever do.  But if you don't mind the length, it's something to look into.  Another issue, is there is absolutely no replayability, which would be fine if the game was a lot longer.

Amusing theme and dialogs.
Story is a bit messy.
Puzzles are simple.
Modern controls.
Way too short.

Absolutely recommended and worth its price :)

If you like not-too-long old-style point & click adventures with an easy gameplay plus whacky British humor, then this is definitely the game for you :D

Actually in my opinion this is one of the best adventure games ever because of:
* the slightly crazy settings
* the unusual events
* topped off with a few elegantly performed pranks being played by our protagonists along the way
* the inordinarily subdued colored sceneries with the right" amount of hotspots while still being rich enough in detail
* and the well-done all-over gameplay-experience.

I quickly came to love the not-too-herolike main characters and the unique secondary characters - the very nice voice-acting had a lot to do with that too ;)

You can play Bertram Fiddle 1 smoothly and bug-free on many platforms.

Chapter 2 of this game has already been funded ( https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/763843992/bertram-fiddle-a-victorian-animated-adventure-game?ref=project_link ) successfully and is currently in the works http://www.bertramfiddle.com.

Like many other adventures delivered in sequels chapter 2 will be a completely new game altogether and not for free. Which I don't mind - I'll definitely get my hands on this continuation as soon as it will be released :) Bertram's FB and Twitter (very funny
date: very recommended) are regularely updated with news about the development if you are interested in how it's advancing."

reviewText:
prosVery quirky, and filled of pop culture references and well delivered puns.
Beautiful palette and smooth animation.
Strong game design, writing and pace.
Characters: your manservant Gavin makes a nice puzzle mechanic, there's a funny archetypal villain, there's ongoing rivalry between you and Sherlock Holmes.
consThere's no character development or in-depth characters to become attached to.
You can't converse with Gavin; a wasted opportunity for character development / humour / hints.
All conversations are linear; less engaging than dialogue trees.
caveatsEasy puzzles.
Contains 2 instances of a timing based mini-game (it's fairly short and easy).
< 2 hours long, ends abruptly, all 3 episodes won't be out until sometime in 2017.
There's no Steam features like achievements, trading cards or cloud saves, and it's 66% cheaper on mobile.

I would recommend this game for those who are looking for a cute and quick story to play through on a rainy day.

Terrifically funny British murder mystery thriller, can definitely see how game is appealing to both children and adults alike. My only critism is that I wanted more, I'd love episode 2 to be longer and more adventureful! Double thumbs up!
This game is amazing and everyone needs to play it.

What an odd little gem.

With a couple of glitches to boot, this charming, funny point and click is definitely worth it, with a hilarious story and intriguing characters, as well as great locations. A lot of the puzzles are solved with a step back, but some do require you to think about it a little more. As a lover of story based games, especially in a comic art style, this really floats my bath- I mean boat.  You'll get that if you play the game.  I can't wait for the second episode, if it truly is as good as the first. A little snippet of Ye Olde London, with a little Sherlock thrown in, this game will have you scratching your head as you piece together someone else's.

Though it is a little short (finishable in under 2 hours) it still is as charming as they come, and if you spent time in the locations, you would truly feel the sense of Olde London, as it is so well conveyed. As mentioned, the art is wonderful, and though occasionally grim, the story will continue to bring a smile to your face, as will Bertram's dialogue.

It can be a little rough around the edges but it's a well done and a quite charming adventure game.\nI do wish it was a little longer but for the price it's not too bad.\nHoping they can get funding for the next episode. I would like to see the story continued.

Filled with amusing art and jokes, Adventure of Bertram Fiddle is quite the distraction. The game's art style reminds me of a cross between Flapjack and Rugrats, with a bit of Victorian flair. Yes, it's filled with puns but they are chuckle/groan (in a good way) worthy. Some were more risque than I expected (but then again, it is Victorian England) but they were also amusing. The gameplay is fun, straight-forward. It is a bit easy--I'm actually quite bad at adventure games (never ever got past any of the first few screens of many Sierra games) but I sailed right through it. However, I suspect future episodes will be more difficult (that happens in these point-and-clicks). If you are itching for a beautiful, funny adventure game, I'd pick this one.

This game is a bit too short for the money, I'd say. But other than that I really like it. It's fun and funny and I like the Edwardian setting. And hey, Sherlock Holmes! And Edgar Allan Poe! Or at least his raven. It's also a simple game, I didn't really get stuck at all. I normally do get stuck.
Such wonderful silly fun.

Synopsis:

In Victorian London, Sherlock Holmes wannabe Bertram Fiddle resides with his faithful cyclopean assistant Gavin (think of a cross between Dr. Watson and Frankenstein’s Igor). They are called into action when, as Bertram is taking his imperious wife’s dog to the groomers, he is bumped into by a dark and mysterious figure leading to a mix-up of the two’s bags, resulting in the sinister assailant making off with Mrs. Fiddle’s precious pooch and leaving the muddled detective with something far less cute and cuddly… a severed head.

Pros:

Both the graphics and voice acting are top-notch.

The delightfully simple animation and art style is a joy with the cartoonishly grotesque character designs creating a wonderfully weird and memorable cast.

Most of the humour manages to hit its target, although admittedly isn’t for everyone as the gags venture greatly into the realm of toilet humour and innuendo

This style of humour compliments the grungy victorian setting whilst also feeling inherently british- the writing didn’t feel too dissimilar to british film studio Aardman Animation, albeit on a much cruder level. This comparison is hardly surprising considering creative director and animator Joe Wood previously worked for the claymation giants, as part of the Flash team.

Its very refreshing to have a point-and-click game that emulates the older classics, where the focus remained on puzzle solving. Lately Telltale Games have set a trend with The Walking Dead series that brings the genre to resemble interactive films, emphasising dialogue trees in cutscenes and action dependent on the player's choices. Whilst a lot of these games are no doubt exceptional, it is still nice to see that the joyous roots of the adventure game have not been forgotten.

A small mechanic that was very much appreciated however was the instant transition to a scene by double clicking on the doorway, thus eliminating the laborious task of watching your character slowly walk from one end of the screen to another when traversing back through the locations- something that is unfortunately present in a lot of old point-and-clicks.

The brisk pace that I was able to progress through the game at helped the entertaining flow of the story.


Cons:

The puzzles themselves, in this first episode at least, are all very simple. There was not one point where I felt particularly challenged or had that magic “ah-ha!” moment when finally figuring out the solution to a head-scratching problem. This will be beneficial for making the game appeal to casual gamers but for veteran fans of the genre the lack of difficulty will prove disappointing.

The simple layout of the game, whilst aesthetically pleasing, doesn’t leave a whole lot of things to click on so it is never really that challenging to decide what needs to be used with what.

The episode was very short, taking roughy two hours to complete. This seems a little on the short side to justify the price of £5.99 that it's going for on Steam, and some players will inevitably feel like they haven’t got their money’s worth. That said, it was at least a very pleasurable two hours, and the player may want to revisit to make sure they didn’t miss any of the witty one-liners.


Bottom Line:

The Adventures of Bertram Fiddle: Episode 1: A Dreadly Business is a highly amusing way to spend a couple of hours. It thrives on humour and style more than it does in-depth gameplay, which is likely to leave non-causal adventure gamers dissatisfied with its brief length and lack of intricate puzzles. The delightfully grimy story and characters, however, carry the game on their own, and personally I am looking forward to spending more time in this world with episode 2.

Beaten in only a few short hours, but worth every penny. Excited for episode 2!

Pros: Puns! Nerdy References! Memorable Characters! Simple Yet Fun Mechanics!

Cons: Too Short!

Bertram Fiddle and his faithful manservant Gavin are in search of adventure. Unfortunately for Bertram, his wife would prefer that he take a boring, but steady paying job. But on the way to taking the dog, Foofy to the groomer, Bertram bumps into a mysterious man and they accidentally exchange cases. The man unknowingly runs off with Foofy. Bertram finds a head in his and realizes that man was Geoff the Murderer. The game's afoot (or at least ahead)!

This is a very short, linear, point-and-click game. You get clues and usable objects both by searching and by running errands for other, odd characters in the game. You also need to combine some object to make them useable. Gavin assists you by being able to move heavy objects.

Keep in mind this is episode 1. They have kickstarted Episode 2. While it's short, the characters are funny and it's an easy game that reminded me a bit of Monty Python. It's about $6 for a game that will take most people only a couple of hours to play.
